questions.text: Among the following, which one is an M phase-specific drug?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Paclitaxel Paclitaxel, is a chemotherapy medication used to treat several types of cancer. This includes ovarian cancer, esophageal cancer, breast cancer, lung cancer, Kaposi's sarcoma, cervical cancer, and pancreatic cancer. It is administered by intravenous injection.

Highyeild:

M phase Vinca alkaloids Taxanes( Paclitaxel) Ixabepilone Estramustine Eribulin Paclitaxel: It is a complex diterpene taxane obtained from the bark of the Western yew tree, which exerts cytotoxic action by a novel mechanism. It binds to β-tubulin and enhances its polymerization to form an excess of microtubules: a mechanism opposite to that of vinca alkaloids. The microtubules are stabilized and their depolymerization is prevented. This stability disrupts the normal dynamic reorganization of the microtubule network that is essential for interphase and mitotic functions.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B. Etoposide is used to treat different cancers of the blood, lung, and testicles. It is also sometimes used to treat some other kinds of cancer in both men and women. It can be used on its own, or sometimes given together with certain other medicines as part of combination chemotherapy. Option: C. Tenopside is a chemotherapeutic medication used in the treatment of childhood acute lymphocytic leukemia (ALL), Hodgkin's lymphoma, certain brain tumors, and other types of cancer. It is in a class of drugs known as podophyllotoxin derivatives and slows the growth of cancer cells. Option: D. Bleomycin is a medication used to treat cancer. This includes Hodgkin's lymphoma, non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, testicular cancer, ovarian cancer, and cervical cancer among others. Typically used with other cancer medications, it can be given intravenously, by injection into a muscle or under the skin.

Extraedge:

Commonly reported side effects of paclitaxel include: hypotension, nausea and vomiting, arthralgia, myalgia, alopecia, diarrhea, hypersensitivity condition, mucositis, skin rash, ecg abnormality, increased serum alkaline phosphatase, increased serum aspartate aminotransferase, infusion site reaction, peripheral neuropathy, and flushing.

Sunitinib Sunitinib is used in the treatment of kidney cancer and gastrointestinal stromal tumor.

questions.text: Purine analogs among the following are?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Clofarabine Clofarabine is a purine nucleoside antimetabolite marketed in the United States and Canada as Clolar. In Europe and Australia/New Zealand, the product is marketed under the name Evoltra. It is FDA-approved for treating relapsed or refractory acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) in children .

Highyeild:

Purine analogs These have structural similarities to purines. They inhibit the enzymes involved in the metabolism of purine nucleotides. Allopurinol: Inhibits xanthine oxidase & used in the treatment of hyperuricemia (gout). 6-mercaptopurine: It inhibits purine nucleotide synthesis & used as an anticancer drug. Metabolic intermediates: These are formed during metabolism of nucleotides g. hypoxanthine, xanthine & uric acid.

Intravenous injection is used for the treatment of colorectal cancer, oesophageal cancer, stomach cancer, pancreatic cancer, breast cancer, and cervical cancer. Option: B. Capecitabine is used in the treatment of cancer of the breast, colon, and rectum. It may be also used to treat other conditions, as determined by the doctor. Option: D. Gemcitabine is used in the treatment of pancreatic cancer, ovarian cancer, breast cancer, urinary bladder cancer, and non-small cell lung cancer.

questions.text: Thalidomide is not used in which of the following condition:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

HIV-associated neuropathy

Highyeild:

Neuropathy is the side effect of thalidomide Thalidomide is now being studied for many conditions. It is indicated in: i. Erythema nodosum leprosum (ENL) ii. Cancer chemotherapy is like – multiple myeloma & myelodysplasia. iii. Crohn’s disease iv. Dermatological conditions – although stomatitis, Behçet’s disease, prurigo, etc. Around 30% of patients develop neuropathy on thalidomide. The selective thalidomide derivative – Lenalidomide is being studied in the management of cancer.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B. Behçet's disease (BD) is a type of inflammatory disorder that affects multiple parts of the body. The most common symptoms include painful sores on the mucous membranes of the mouth and other parts of the body, inflammation of parts of the eye, and arthritis. Option: C. Hiv associated oral ulcer , HIV can cause the salivary glands to swell, which can lead to reduced saliva production and dry mouth. Saliva protects the teeth and gums from plaque and helps fight off infection. A dry mouth can also be a side effect of HIV medications. Option: D. Erythema nodosum leprosum (ENL) is an immune-mediated complication of leprosy, characterized by the presence of multiple inflammatory cutaneous nodules and systemic symptoms such as fever, malaise, arthritis, iritis, neuritis, and lymphadenitis.

questions.text: A 49-year-old woman diagnosed with stage IV adenocarcinoma of the lung started the first cycle of anticancer chemotherapy. The regimen included a drug that binds to tubulin and prevents microtubule disassembly. Which of the following drugs has this mechanism of action?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Paclitaxel Reason-Although adenocarcinoma of the lung is less sensitive than small cell lung cancer to chemotherapy, combination therapy can improve survival. A widely used first-line regimen includes a platinum compound (e.g., cisplatin), and a taxane (e.g., paclitaxel). Taxanes bind to tubulin and inhibit tubulin depolymerization, thus preventing microtubule disassembly.

Highyeild:

Paclitaxel a potent cytotoxic agent mechanism of action interferes with mitotic spindle function block the cell in the G2/M phase of the cell cycle ↑ apoptosis and tumor reoxygenation also may occur binds to & stabilizes microtubules - loss of microtubule dynamics > impair the mitotic spindle preventing microtubule depolymerization

Explanation for incorrect options:- Options A, B, and D- These drugs are not used for lung cancer and they do not bind to tubulin.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy suffering from acute lymphoblastic leukemia started maintenance therapy that included high-dose methotrexate. Two weeks later, a blood test showed a white blood cell count of 1800/m m 3 (normal 4500−11,000/m m3). The oncologist believed the result was related to an excessive dose of methotrexate and ordered an antidote agent. Which of the following drugs would be appropriate for the patient at this time?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Leucovorin

Highyeild:

Leucovorin can be given to counteract the adverse effects that methotrexate has on normal cells. Leucovorin (formyl tetrahydrofolate, also called folinic acid) is accumulated more readily by normal cells than by neoplastic cells. The administration of this drug results in the rescue of the normal cells, because the drug bypasses the step in the purine synthesis that is blocked by methotrexate (i.e., dihydrofolate to tetrahydrofolate).

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Vitamin B12:Pemetrexed toxicity Option: B. Pyridoxine: INH toxicity Option: C. Folic acid: Pemetrexed toxicity Options A, B, and C are not antidotes to methotrexate, hence incorrect.

Extraedge:

Folate antagonist: Methotrexate Adverse effects: MTX causes stomatitis, myelosuppression, erythema, rash, urticaria, and alopecia. Most frequent toxicities: nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. Adverse effects can be prevented or reversed by administering leucovorin. Hepatic function: Long-term use of MTX may lead to cirrhosis. Renal function: Variable Neurologic toxicities: subacute meningeal irritation, stiff neck, headache, and fever. Rarely, seizures, encephalopathy or paraplegia occur. Contraindications: Because MTX is teratogenic in experimental animals and is an abortifacient, it should be avoided in pregnancy.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy recently diagnosed with Wilms tumor was started on a combination anticancer therapy that included vincristine. Inhibition of which of the following functions in cancer cells most likely mediated the drug's therapeutic effect in the patient’s disease?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Tubulin polymerization Tubulin polymerization , Microtubules function in many essential cellular processes, including mitosis. Tubulin-binding drugs kill cancerous cells by inhibiting microtubule dynamics, which are required for DNA segregation and cell division.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option : A. Vincristine and vinblastine are vinca alkaloids. These drugs bind specifically to β-tubulin, the structural proteins that form microtubules, and block β-tubulin polymerization with α-tubulin, thus preventing microtubule assembly. In this way, they cause an arrest of the mitotic cycle in metaphase. Options B, C, and D are incorrect as inhibition of tubulin polymerization is needed to mediate the therapeutic effect of vincristine.

questions.text: Raju 55-year-old man presents with progressively worsening shortness of breath and new-onset hemoptysis. He was a chronic smoker. A chest X-ray reveals a circular lesion in the right upper lobe. He begins taking methotrexate as part of a chemotherapy regimen. Which is a potential complication of methotrexate therapy?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Macrocytic anemia Reason-Macrocytic anemia. Methotrexate is a folate antimetabolite. It inhibits the enzyme dihydrofolate reductase, which is necessary for recycling folate from its oxidized form to its usable, reduced form, tetrahydrofolate. Without tetrahydrofolate, cells cannot replicate DNA. This not only makes methotrexate useful against the rapidly dividing cells of cancer but may also significantly impair DNA synthesis in normal cells with prolonged use. In particular, extended use of methotrexate can disrupt the mitosis of hematopoietic cells and lead to megaloblastic anemia, a form of macrocytic anemia.

Highyeild:

Causes of Macrocytic anemia (ABCDEF) A- Alcohol + liver disease B- B 12 deficiency C- Compensatory reticulocytes D- Drugs(cytotoxic and AZT), Dysplasia of bone marrow E- Endocrine (Hypothyroidism) F- Folate deficiency

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A & B - Thalassemia is a genetic anemia caused by the loss of function of one or more globin genes. Methotrexate does not cause a-thalassemia. Option: D - Microcytic anemia occurs when hematopoietic cell growth is slowed but the rate of DNA synthesis is unchanged. Methotrexate impairs DNA synthesis , so would not result in microcytic anemia

Extraedge:

Refractory Anemia RA Definition: Dyplasia of the erythroid series only. Clinically, anemia is refractory to hematinic therapy Myeloblasts <1% blood and < 5% marrow <15% ringed sideroblasts in marrow No Auer rods Other etiologies of erythroid abnormalities must be excluded. These include: drug/toxin exposure Vitamin deficiency Viral infection Congenital disease
